titleStmt.title: The interplay of emotional and social conceptual processes during moral reasoning in frontotemporal dementia -a role for the uncinate fasciculus

analytic.title: The interplay of emotional and social conceptual processes during moral reasoning in frontotemporal dementia -a role for the uncinate fasciculus

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Cooperative social behaviour in humans hinges upon our unique ability to make appropriate moral decisions in accordance with our ethical values. The complexity of the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying moral reasoning is revealed when this capacity breaks down. Patients with the behavioural variant of frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) display striking moral transgressions in the context of atrophy to frontotemporal regions supporting affective and social conceptual processing. Developmental studies have highlighted the importance of social knowledge to moral decision making in children, yet the role of social knowledge in relation to moral reasoning impairments in neurodegeneration has largely been overlooked. Here, we sought to examine the role of affective and social conceptual processes in personal moral reasoning in bvFTD, and their relationship to the integrity and structural connectivity of frontotemporal brain regions. Personal moral reasoning across varying degrees of conflict was assessed in 26 bvFTD patients and compared with demographically matched Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients (n = 14), and healthy older adults (n = 22). Following each moral decision, we directly probed participants' subjective emotional experience as an index of their affective response, while social norm knowledge was assessed via an independent task. While groups did not differ significantly in terms of their moral decisions, bvFTD patients reported feeling better about their decisions than healthy Controls. In other words, although bvFTD patients could adjudicate between different courses of action in the moral scenarios, their affective responses to these decisions were highly irregular. This blunted emotional reaction was exclusive to the personal high-conflict condition, with 61.5% of bvFTD patients reporting feeling 'extremely good' about their decisions, and was correlated with reduced knowledge of socially acceptable behaviour. Voxel-based morphometry analyses revealed a distributed network of frontal, subcortical, and lateral temporal grey matter regions involved in the attenuated affective response to moral conflict in bvFTD. Crucially, diffusion-tensor imaging implicated the uncinate fasciculus as the pathway by which social conceptual knowledge may influence emotional reactions to personal high-conflict moral dilemmas in bvFTD. Our findings suggest that altered moral behaviour in bvFTD reflects the dynamic interplay between degraded social conceptual knowledge and blunted affective responsiveness, attributable to atrophy of, and impaired information transfer between, frontal and temporal cortices. Delineating the mechanisms of impaired morality in bvFTD provides crucial clinical information for understanding and treating this challenging symptom, which may help pave the way for targeted behavioural interventions.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In everyday life, we routinely make swift and effective moral judgments in accordance with our ethical values -a uniquely human attribute which forms the backbone of co-operative social behaviour. This capacity for moral reasoning has been the subject of vigorous philosophical debate (Hamlin, 2013;Nichols, 2005), most notably in relation to its origins and development throughout childhood. Specifically, the internalisation of societal rules (Piaget, 1932) and maturity of social emotions such as guilt, shame, and empathy (Hoffman, 1979) have emerged as key mechanisms underpinning the development of morality in children. What is less clear, however, is how these social, conceptual, and emotional processes unravel in neurodegenerative brain disorders. The study of moral reasoning in dementia offers a unique opportunity to characterise the neurocognitive mechanisms which must be functional to support highly sophisticated socioemotional processes (Irish, Piguet, & Hodges, 2012).

Contemporary studies of moral reasoning in adults have tended to invoke a dual processaccount to describe how emotional and rational processes compete (Cushman, Young, & Greene, 2010), particularly when deliberating on 'personal' versus 'impersonal' moral dilemmas (Greene, Sommerville, Nystrom, Darley, & Cohen, 2001). Personal moral scenarios involve a decision to inflict direct harm on another individual (e.g., the footbridge problem, Thomson, 1976), and are thought to be heavily based on intuitive, emotional processes (Valdesolo & DeSteno, 2006). By contrast, 'impersonal' moral dilemmas (e.g., the trolley problem, Foot, 1967) preferentially draw upon controlled cognitive processing (Greene, Morelli, Lowenberg, Nystrom, & Cohen, 2008). Functional neuroimaging and lesion studies support this account, with an affective brain network anchored on the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) implicated in personal moral reasoning, while lateral prefrontal regions have been associated with responses to impersonal dilemmas (reviewed by Pascual, Rodrigues, & Gallardo-Pujol, 2013). Accumulating evidence, however, challenges this dichotomous approach, and suggests that additional cognitive processes may be involved in personal moral reasoning (e.g., McCormick, Rosenthal, Miller, & Maguire, 2016). Notably, social conceptual knowledge has been speculated to play an important role, whereby social rules and norms represented in anterior temporal lobes (ATLs) may be drawn upon to inform personal moral decisions (Allison, Puce, & McCarthy, 2000;Moll, Zahn, de Oliveira-Souza, Krueger, & Grafman, 2005). Empirical evidence for this perspective, however, is lacking. As such, it is unclear to what extent social conceptual knowledge contributes to personal moral reasoning, and how it may interact with emotional processes in supporting this endeavour.

One particularly fruitful avenue for exploring the mechanisms of moral reasoning is to study everyday examples of its breakdown. The behavioural variant of frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) offers a unique glimpse into the degeneration of the "social brain" given its hallmark alterations in personality and behaviour, including emotional blunting, loss of empathy, and an inability to consider the thoughts and perspectives of others (Dermody et al., 2016;Strikwerda-Brown, Ramanan, & Irish, 2019;Synn et al., 2018). These symptoms arise due to early degeneration of large-scale functional brain networks specialised for socioemotional functioning, centered on medial prefrontal and frontoinsular cortices (Seeley, Zhou, & Kim, 2012). With disease progression, atrophy gradually encroaches into lateral temporal areas (Landin-Romero et al., 2017;Rosen et al., 2002) that support the processing of semantic and socioemotional concepts (Olson, McCoy, Klobusicky, & Ross, 2013;Zahn et al., 2007).

Importantly, the frontotemporal regions harbouring early atrophy in bvFTD are consistently implicated in fMRI studies of personal moral reasoning in healthy individuals (Pascual et al., 2013), suggesting this capacity would be significantly compromised in this syndrome. Indeed, anecdotal evidence points to striking moral transgressions in bvFTD, ranging from acts of aggression, to urination in public, and making inappropriate sexual remarks to strangers (Mendez, Chen, Shapira, & Miller, 2005;. In some cases, these behaviours can result in criminal offences, including theft, violence, hypersexuality, traffic violations, and even homicide (Liljegren et al., 2015).

To date, only a handful of studies have explored potential mechanisms mediating personal moral reasoning difficulties in bvFTD. Unsurprisingly, as emotional disturbances are a canonical feature of bvFTD, the majority of studies examining personal moral reasoning in this syndrome have placed particular emphasis on affective contributions. For example, the finding of increased utilitarian responses (i.e., 'for the greater good') to personal, but not impersonal, dilemmas in bvFTD compared with healthy controls has been suggested to reflect a diminished response to emotionally charged scenarios (Chiong et al., 2013;Fong et al., 2017;Mendez, Anderson, & Shapira, 2005;Mendez & Shapira, 2009;Van den Stock et al., 2017). Direct support for this proposal comes from the observation of decreased autonomic arousal and diminished emotional reactivity in bvFTD patients during personal moral decision-making (Fong et al., 2017). Moreover, utilitarian responses to personal moral dilemmas in bvFTD have been shown to correlate with poor performance on an independent measure of facial emotion recognition (Van den Stock et al., 2017). On the neural level, these responses have been linked to structural and functional changes in medial prefrontal, insular, and anterior cingulate cortices (Chiong et al., 2013;Van den Stock et al., 2017), particularly in the right hemisphere (Mendez & Shapira, 2009). As such, the evidence to date suggests that impairments in personal moral reasoning in bvFTD are linked to attenuated emotional responsivity due to frontoinsular degeneration.

What remains less clear, however, is the role of social conceptual knowledge in moral reasoning difficulties in bvFTD. Deficits in semantic processing (Williams, Nestor, & Hodges, 2005), including decreased knowledge of social rules and concepts (Panchal et al., 2016), are commonplace in bvFTD, particularly with encroachment of atrophy into ATLs. In this regard, it is notable that increased utilitarian responses to personal moral dilemmas have been associated with reduced perfusion/metabolism within the bilateral ATLs in bvFTD (Mendez & Shapiro, 2009). While the processes underlying this association have not been explored, it is intuitive to propose that ATL dysfunction in these patients may hinder the consideration of social rules and norms during personal moral reasoning, resulting in aberrant moral decisions.

More recent findings in a small group of patients hint at a role for social conceptual knowledge in moral reasoning in bvFTD, with a correlation emerging between the understanding of social norms and experimenter ratings of patients' emotional reactivity toward a single personal moral dilemma (Fong et al., 2017). Thus while the majority of studies on moral reasoning in bvFTD have focused on affective contributions, mediated by mPFC/frontoinsular regions, careful consideration of the extant literature suggests that social knowledge, supported by the ATLs, should also play a modulating role. Crucially, structural connectivity between the mPFC and ATLs via the uncinate fasciculus (UF) is compromised from early in the bvFTD disease trajectory (Lam, Halliday, Irish, Hodges, & Piguet, 2014). It is therefore possible that altered communication between regions supporting affective processing (i.e., mPFC) and those implicated in social conceptual knowledge (i.e., ATL) disrupt personal moral reasoning performance in this syndrome.

The objectives of the current study were four-fold. First, we sought to establish the nature of personal moral reasoning disturbances across varying degrees of conflict (Koenigs et al., 2007) in a large, well-characterised sample of bvFTD patients, and to contrast their performance with a disease control group of amnestic Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients. Second, we directly tested the contribution of impairments in affective responding to task performance in bvFTD by probing participants' own emotional experience following each morally conflicting decision. Third, to determine the potential role of social conceptual knowledge during highly conflicting moral deliberations, we included an objective measure of social rule understanding.

Finally, we used whole-brain multimodal structural neuroimaging to determine the grey-and white-matter correlates of personal moral reasoning in bvFTD. We predicted that both emotional responding and social conceptual knowledge would contribute to personal moral reasoning deficits in bvFTD, reflecting the degeneration of mPFC and ATLs, and crucially, the white-matter tracts connecting these regions.

div.head: Participants
div.p: Twenty-six patients with bvFTD, 14 AD patients, and 22 healthy Control participants completed this study. All participants were able to understand and follow task instructions.

Dementia patients met current international consensus criteria for bvFTD (Rascovsky et al., Recall; Schmidt, 1996) and nonverbal (Rey Complex Figure [RCF] 3 minute recall; Rey, 1941) episodic memory, and executive function (Trail Making Test Part B-A; Tombaugh, 2004).

Behavioural change was assessed using the Cambridge Behavioural Inventory (CBI Total Frequency Score; Wedderburn et al., 2008), and the Clinical Dementia Rating Scale-Frontotemporal Lobar Degeneration (CDR-FTLD Sum of Boxes [SOB]; Knopman et al., 2008) was employed as an index of disease severity.

div.head: Moral reasoning task
div.p: Participants completed a moral reasoning task, adapted from Koenigs et al. (2007). Fourteen of the original 50 hypothetical scenarios were selected for the current study. These scenarios were representative of the full set of dilemmas (see Supplementary Methods for further detail).

The shortened version of the task lasted approximately 30-45 minutes, compared to >60 minutes for the original version. This reduced task length was chosen to accommodate the cognitive abilities of the dementia patients, reduce the potential for participant distress, and avoid patient fatigue.

The 14 scenarios fell into four categories. Neutral scenarios (n = 4) were practical dilemmas without a moral component (e.g., choosing whether to buy a new DVD player, or have your old one fixed, for the same price). These scenarios acted as a control condition to ensure appropriate task understanding and compliance. Impersonal moral dilemmas (n = 4) required a choice whether to sacrifice the life of one person in order to save multiple lives, via the deflection of an existing threat (e.g., the traditional 'trolley problem', whereby flicking a switch would divert a runaway train from the track with five people on it, to a track with one person), or involved morally conflictual scenarios that did not require the infliction of direct personal harm (e.g., choosing whether to commit tax fraud). Personal moral dilemmas, requiring a choice to personally harm somebody in order to save multiple lives, were divided into High (n = 4) and Low (n = 2) Conflict scenarios. While Personal Low Conflict moral dilemmas involve rather inexcusable actions, which are often rejected by healthy individuals (e.g., committing cannibalism to save oneself and others), Personal High Conflict moral dilemmas (e.g., killing a fellow hostage so that oneself and others may escape from terrorists) are more divisive, and better differentiate between patient and control groups (Koenigs et al., 2007;McCormick et al., 2016) 1 .

Where necessary, phrasing of the scenarios was modified slightly from the original task for cultural appropriateness in an Australian context (e.g., exchanging 'watchman' for 'security guard'). The full text of all scenarios is provided in Supplementary Material, along with their original versions. Scenarios were presented in pseudorandomised order in text format on a Microsoft PowerPoint presentation, and concurrently read aloud by the examiner to further ensure task understanding and compliance.
Each of the 14 dilemmas, along with one practice dilemma, consisted of five slides. An example five-slide trial for a Personal High Conflict moral dilemma is depicted in Figure 1.

The first slide displayed the scenario, ending with a yes/no question about the hypothetical action ("Would you … in order to …?"). No time limit was set, though if a response was not provided within approximately 15 seconds of the examiner reading the scenario, generic prompting was provided (e.g., re-reading of the question). Responses were classed as either Utilitarian (i.e., the maximising of aggregate welfare) or Deontological (i.e., a refusal to do harm). The percentage of Utilitarian decisions was calculated for each moral dilemma type (i.e., Impersonal, Personal Low Conflict, Personal High Conflict), for use in analysis.

In order to explore the mechanisms underlying moral decision making, the next four slides contained a series of follow-up questions regarding the decision-making process. Participants were required to rate "How sure are you about this decision?" (on a scale of 'Extremely Unsure'

(1) to 'Extremely Sure' (5)), "How do you feel about your decision?" (on a scale of 'Extremely Bad' (1) to 'Extremely Good' (5)) and "How vividly did you picture this scenario in your mind's eye?" (on a scale of 'Not Vividly at All (1) to 'Extremely Vividly' (5)). The average certainty, feeling, and vividness ratings were calculated for each of the moral dilemma types.

Finally, to capture the moral decision-making process, participants were asked the open-ended question: "How did you make your decision?" following every trial. During the practice trial at the beginning of the task, example responses to this question were provided (e.g., picturing the scene in the 'mind's eye'; emotions/gut reaction; knowledge of right/wrong; future consequences/outcome). In the main task, however, participants were encouraged to respond using their own words 2 . If the response was unclear, generic prompts were provided (e.g., "Can you tell me anything else about how you made your decision?"). Responses were later classed into either emotional (i.e., based on emotional reactions, or personal/societal beliefs about right and wrong) or rational (i.e., considering the outcome, or picturing the scene), consistent with McCormick et al. (2016). A proportion of emotional reasons was then calculated for each dilemma type, by dividing the number of emotional responses by the number of dilemmas.
Example responses of each type are provided in Supplementary Material.

div.head: Social norms questionnaire
div.p: To explore the effect of social conceptual knowledge on moral decision making, the Social Norms Questionnaire (SNQ; Possin et al., 2013) was administered. The SNQ measures the ability to identify socially appropriate and inappropriate behaviours. For each of the 22 items, participants are required to respond yes or no as to whether a hypothetical behaviour would be considered socially appropriate in mainstream local culture. To ensure cultural appropriateness for an Australian sample, slight modifications were made to the phrasing of the original version (e.g., switching 'sidewalk' to 'footpath'; see Supplementary Material for a comparison of the two versions). Total number of errors was calculated, with higher values reflecting poorer social knowledge. Separate scores were also obtained for errors on the 'Break Norms' (rating socially unacceptable behaviours as acceptable, e.g., telling a stranger you don't like their hairstyle), and 'Overadherence' (rating socially acceptable behaviours as unacceptable, e.g., telling a stranger you like their hairstyle) subscales.

div.head: Statistical analyses
div.p: First, Kolmogorov-Smirnov (K-S) tests were performed to determine the suitability of variables for parametric analyses. Experimental variables that were non-normally distributed (i.e., K-S test p < .05 in one or both patient groups) were logarithmically transformed, though for ease of interpretation, untransformed values are presented in figures. One-way analyses of variance were employed to assess group differences on demographic measures and neuropsychological tasks. Frequencies of dichotomous variables (i.e., sex) were compared with chi-squared tests (c 2 ). Given significant differences in years of formal education between bvFTD and Controls, education was included as a covariate for all main between-group analyses on the experimental task. First, repeated measures ANCOVAs were used to investigate main effects of group (bvFTD, AD, Control) and dilemma type (Impersonal, Personal Low-Conflict, Personal High-Conflict), and their interaction, on the percentage of Utilitarian responses provided followed by Sidak post hoc tests where appropriate. For the subjective ratings, non-parametric Kruskal Wallis tests, were run to examine between-group differences in average Certainty, Feeling and Vividness ratings followed by Dunn-Bonferroni tests where relevant. Univariate ANCOVA was used to investigate between-group differences in the proportion of emotional reasons given for the decisions. For the SNQ, a repeatedmeasures ANCOVA, followed by Sidak post hoc tests, was employed to explore main effects of group and error type (Rule Break, Overadhere), and their interaction. Finally, Spearman's correlations were employed to examine the relationship between moral reasoning performance and the SNQ questionnaire. The significance level was set at p < .05 for all analyses. Effect sizes were calculated using partial eta-squared (hp 2 ) for parametric analyses and eta-squared (h 2 ) for nonparametric analyses.

div.head: Structural MRI: Image acquisition
div.p: Participants underwent T1-weighted structural brain neuroimaging using a 3Tesla GE MRI scanner with standard quadrature head coil (eight channels). The 3D T1-weighted images were acquired using the following sequences: coronal orientation, matrix 256 × 256, 200 slices, 1 × 1 mm in-plane resolution, slice thickness = 1mm, echo time/repetition = 2.6/5.8 ms, flip angle α = 8°.

div.head: Structural MRI: Data preprocessing
div.p: MRI data were analysed with FSL-VBM (Functional MRI of the Brain (FMRIB) Software Library; Ashburner & Friston, 2000), using the toolbox from the FMRIB software package (http://www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/fslvbm/index.html; Smith et al., 2004). Images were first extracted using the Brain Extraction Tool (BET; Smith, 2002), then tissue was segmented into grey and white matter and cerebrospinal fluid using FMRIB's Automatic Segmentation Tool (FAST; Zhang, Brady, & Smith, 2001). The resulting grey matter partial volume maps were aligned to the Montreal Neurological Institute standard space (MNI152) using the FMRIB Non-linear Image Registration Tool (FNIRT; Andersson, Jenkinson, & Smith, 2007) which uses a b-spline representation of the registration warp field (Rueckert et al., 1999). A studyspecific template was then created from the resulting images, to which the native grey matter images were re-registered non-linearly. Modulation of the registered partial volume maps was conducted by dividing them by the Jacobian of the warp field. Finally, the modulated, segmented images were smoothed with an isotropic Gaussian kernel with a sigma of 3mm.

div.head: Voxel-based morphometry analysis
div.p: Given that the significant difference on the moral reasoning task emerged between bvFTD and Control participants only, voxel-based morphometry analyses were conducted in these two groups (i.e., not including AD patients).

For analyses of grey matter intensity, permutation-based non-parametric testing was employed using unbiased whole-brain General Linear Models (GLM) in FSL, with 5,000 permutations per contrast (Nichols & Holmes, 2002). Differences in grey matter intensity between bvFTD and Controls were assessed using t-tests, including age and education as covariates of no interest. Significant clusters were extracted using the threshold-free cluster enhancement (TFCE) method at a strict threshold of p < .005, corrected for multiple comparisons via familywise error (FWE) correction, with a cluster extent cut-off of 200 contiguous voxels.

Next, correlations between the moral reasoning variable that significantly differed between bvFTD and Controls (i.e., feeling rating for Personal High Conflict dilemmas) and grey matter intensity were investigated. For this analysis, a negative contrast was employed, providing an index of association between higher (i.e., more positive/more abnormal) feeling ratings and decreased grey matter intensity. Consistent with previous studies, these correlation analyses were performed on bvFTD patients combined with Controls, in order to provide greater variance in behaviour scores, and therefore increase the statistical power to detect brainbehaviour relationships (Sollberger et al., 2009). Age and education were included as covariates of no interest. Significant clusters were extracted using the TFCE method at a threshold of p < .01, FWE corrected, with a cluster extent cut-off of 200 contiguous voxels.

Together, the statistical approaches for these neuroimaging analyses take into consideration the relatively large sample size and balance the risk of Type I versus Type II errors (see Lieberman & Cunningham, 2009).

Significant results were overlaid on the MNI standard brain, with maximum co-ordinates provided in MNI stereotaxic space. Anatomical labels were determined with reference to the Harvard-Oxford probabilistic cortical and subcortical atlases.

div.head: Diffusion-weighted MRI: Image acquisition
div.p: Whole-brain echo planar images with 64 noncollinear gradient directions were collected using the following sequences: matrix 96 x 96mm, 55 slices, voxel size = 2.5mm 3 repetition time/echo time/inversion time: 8400/68/90msec, b-value = 1000 sec/mm 2 , field of view = 240
x 240mm.

div.head: Diffusion-weighted MRI: Preprocessing
div.p: Tract-based Spatial Statistics (TBSS) in FSL were employed to perform a skeleton-based analysis of white matter fractional anisotropy (FA). Raw diffusion-weighted images for each participant were corrected for eddy-currents and co-registered using nonlinear registration to MNI standard space using their respective 3D T1-weighted structural MR image. Given the coarse resolution of diffusion-weighted imaging data (i.e., 2.5mm 3 ), this template was subsampled at 2mm 3 . Following image registration, a tensor model was fitted to the diffusionweighted image and FA maps were generated for each participant. FA maps were then averaged to produce a group mean FA image. A skeletonised algorithm was applied to define a group template of the lines of maximum FA (Smith et al., 2006), corresponding to the centres of the white matter tracts. Finally, FA values for each participant were projected onto the group template skeleton.

div.head: Diffusion tensor imaging analyses
div.p: Diffusion tensor imaging analyses were conducted to examine whole-brain changes in white matter microstructure (i.e., fractional anisotropy; FA). FA values were compared between bvFTD and Control groups using permutation-based non-parametric testing in FSL as outlined for the VBM analysis (above). Age and education were included as nuisance variables in this analysis. Significant clusters were extracted using the TFCE method and corrected for FWE at p < .05. The Johns Hopkins University probabilistic white matter atlas and the ICBM-DTI-WM atlas were used to determine anatomical labels.

Masks of selected white matter tracts of interest, namely the uncinate fasciculus (UF) and inferior longitudinal fasciculus (ILF), were created from the Johns Hopkins University probabilistic white matter atlas. The UF was chosen as the main white matter tract of interest given it is the primary tract connecting regions that correlated with moral reasoning performance in the VBM analyses (i.e., mPFC/orbitofrontal cortex and ATLs (Von Der Heide, Skipper, Klobusicky, & Olson, 2013). The ILF, which connects the ATL to the occipital lobe (Herbet, Zemmoura, & Duffau, 2018), was chosen as a tract of no interest to examine the specificity of the current findings. Correlations between FA values of these tracts, extracted for each participant, and moral reasoning performance (i.e., feeling rating for Personal High Conflict moral dilemmas) were examined in the bvFTD group using one-way Spearman's correlations.

div.head: Data availability
div.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available on request from the corresponding author. The data are not publicly available due to the ethical requirement to ensure patient confidentiality.

div.head: Clinical characteristics
div.p: Participant demographics and cognitive performance are displayed in Table 1. Groups did not significantly differ in age (p = .40) or sex (p = .10), but Controls were more educated than bvFTD patients (p = .02). Patient groups did not significantly differ in terms of disease duration (i.e., months since symptom onset; p = .06) or disease severity (CDR-FTLD SoB: p = .96).

Both bvFTD and AD patients demonstrated significant behavioural change compared with Controls (CBI: p < .001 and p = .004, respectively), though these symptoms were more frequent in bvFTD than AD (p = .007).

div.head: Neuropsychological performance
div.p: Patient groups displayed characteristic cognitive profiles on standard neuropsychological assessment (Table 1). bvFTD patients showed impairments in global cognitive functioning (ACE-III Total) (p < .001), verbal attention (Digit Span Forward) (p = .01), verbal episodic memory (RAVLT Delayed Recall) (p < .001), and executive function (Trails B-A) (p = .01) compared with Controls. By contrast, verbal working memory (Digit Span Backwards) (p = .17), language (ACE-III Language) (p = .06), and visual episodic memory (RCF Recall) (p = .33) were relatively preserved. Relative to Controls, AD patients displayed significant impairments in global cognitive functioning (p < .001), verbal working memory (p = .003), language (p = .04), verbal (p < .001) and nonverbal (p < .001) episodic memory, and executive function (p < .001), along with the suggestion of verbal attention deficits (p = .052).

Relative to bvFTD, AD patients were significantly more impaired on measures of verbal (p = .048) and nonverbal (p < .001) episodic memory, and executive function (p = .02). Patient groups did not significantly differ on any other neuropsychological tasks. allocated the maximum time allowed of 300 seconds (6 bvFTD, 4 AD).

div.head: Moral reasoning task performance
div.p: To establish that participants could comprehend and response appropriately on the task, we first explored potential group differences on the Neutral (control) dilemmas. Importantly, no significant differences were found between the groups in terms of their decisions or ratings on the neutral dilemmas (Supplementary Results), indicating that all participants understood and could complete the task appropriately. Inspection of the individual responses of participants revealed that 3 Controls, 1 bvFTD, and 3 AD patients responded counterintuitively to one out of four of the neutral scenarios; however, their verbal explanations for these decisions indicated that these participants had nonetheless understood the dilemma (e.g., responding that they would rather save 15 minutes off a car trip than take the beautiful scenic route). Degrees of freedom were therefore corrected for this variable using Huynh-Feldt estimates of sphericity (ε = .82).

A significant main effect of dilemma type emerged (F(1.52, 93.84) = 6.22, p = .005, hp 2 = .10), such that participants provided a greater percentage of Utilitarian responses for Impersonal moral dilemmas compared with Personal Low-and High Conflict dilemmas (p < .001 and .046, respectively). A higher percentage of Utilitarian responses was also observed for Personal

High-compared to Low-Conflict dilemmas (p < .001). This pattern of results is consistent with previous findings with studies employing the full set of 50 scenarios (Koenigs et al., 2007;McCormick et al., 2016), confirming the validity of the subset of the dilemmas chosen for the current task.

By contrast, no significant main effect of group (F(2, 57) = 1.34, p = .27 hp 2 = .05), or interaction between group and dilemma type (F(3.29, 93.84) = .60 p = .64, hp 2 = .02), on the responses to the moral dilemmas was observed ( [ INSERT FIGURE 2 HERE] Given previous findings of alterations specific to personal moral reasoning in bvFTD (Chiong et al., 2013;Fong et al., 2017;Mendez, Anderson, et al., 2005;Mendez & Shapira, 2009;Van den Stock et al., 2017), further analyses were conducted on the follow-up questions to Personal Low and High Conflict dilemmas (Figure 3). For Personal Low Conflict dilemmas, using

Kruskal Wallis tests, no significant difference between groups was apparent for any of the ratings (certainty: c 2 = .79, p = .67, h 2 = -.05; vividness: c 2 = 3.24, p = .20, h 2 = .02; feeling: c 2 = 1.13, p = .57, h 2 = -.01). For Personal High Conflict dilemmas, ratings did not significantly differ between the groups for certainty (c 2 = 1.54, p = .46, h 2 = .008) or vividness (c 2 = .87, p = .65, h 2 = .019) ratings. Importantly, a significant between-group effect emerged for feeling ratings (c 2 = 6.68, p = .04, h 2 = .079) in the Personal High conflict condition. Follow-up Dunn-Bonferroni comparisons revealed that bvFTD patients reported feeling better about their decisions on Personal High Conflict moral dilemmas than Controls (p = .03). No differences in feeling ratings for the Personal High Conflict dilemmas were apparent between AD and Controls (p = .34), or AD and bvFTD patients (p = 1.00).

[ INSERT FIGURE 3 HERE] Finally, no significant differences were found between the groups in terms of the reasons given for their moral decisions on either Personal Low (F(2, 57) = .60, p = .42, h 2 = .02) or High conflict dilemmas (F(2, 57) = .54, p = .58, hp 2 = .02). Namely, all groups provided relatively equal proportions of emotional (versus rational) reasons for their decisions (Personal Low Control: M = .50, SD = .24) 3 .

div.head: Social norms questionnaire (SNQ)
div.p: For the SNQ, a main effect of group emerged (F(2, 58) = 3.87, p = .03, hp 2 =.12), such that bvFTD patients made more errors in social norm judgment, compared with Controls (p = .02) ( Supplementary Figure 1) This impairment in bvFTD replicates that found in previous studies using the unmodified version of the SNQ (Carr et al., 2015;Panchal et al., 2016;Possin et al., 2013), as well as findings using our same modified version in a separate bvFTD sample (Wilson, Ahmed, Hodges, Piguet, & Irish, 2020), demonstrating the validity of the current measure. No significant differences were observed on the SNQ between AD and Controls (p = .57), or between the patient groups (p = .46). A main effect of error type (Rule Break, Overadhere) was also apparent (F(1, 58) = 4.43, p = .04, hp 2 = .07), with participants making significantly more overadherence than rule break errors. By contrast, no significant interaction between group and error type emerged (F(2, 58) = .94, p = .40, hp 2 = .03), suggesting the impairment in social conceptual knowledge in bvFTD was not specific to, or driven by, either error type.

div.head: Correlations between emotional response to Personal High Conflict moral dilemmas and social conceptual knowledge
div.p: To examine the contribution of social conceptual knowledge to personal moral reasoning performance in bvFTD, the relationship between feeling ratings toward Personal High-Conflict moral dilemmas (i.e., the moral reasoning measure showing a significant difference between bvFTD and Controls) and Total score on the SNQ was examined in the bvFTD group using Spearman's correlation coefficient. A significant negative correlation emerged, such that higher errors on the SNQ (denoting poorer social conceptual knowledge) related to a blunted emotional response following Personal High-Conflict moral decisions (r = -.43, p = .03).

div.head: Voxel-based morphometry analyses: Group differences in grey matter intensity
div.p: VBM analyses revealed a characteristic pattern of grey matter atrophy in the bvFTD group.

Briefly, compared with Controls, bvFTD patients displayed reduced grey matter intensity in predominantly frontal and temporal lobes, including bilateral frontal pole, orbitofrontal cortex, and medial and lateral prefrontal cortex, extending into bilateral anterior and medial temporal lobes and subcortical regions including basal ganglia and amygdala (Figure 4 and Supplementary Table 1).

div.head: [INSERT FIGURE 4 HERE]
div.p: Voxel-based morphometry analyses: Neural correlates of moral reasoning performance

In bvFTD and Control participants combined, a more positive feeling rating toward Personal High Conflict moral dilemmas (i.e., less remorse) was associated with decreased grey matter intensity in frontal and subcortical regions including mPFC, orbitofrontal cortex, dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, anterior cingulate cortex, insula, amygdala, anterior hippocampus, and basal ganglia, as well as bilateral ATLs ( Figure 5 and Table 2; see also Supplementary Figure 2 for scatterplot).
[INSERT FIGURE 5 HERE]

div.head: Diffusion tensor imaging analyses
div.p: DTI analyses revealed a typical profile of white matter atrophy in bvFTD patients compared with Controls, in the bilateral uncinate fasciculi (UF), inferior fronto-occipital fasciculi, forceps minor, superior longitudinal fasciculi, and corpus callosum; and left cingulate, forceps major and inferior longitudinal fasciculus (ILF).

The UF was explored as the main white matter tract of interest given it is the primary tract connecting the mPFC/orbitofrontal cortex to the ATLs (Von Der Heide et al., 2013): grey matter regions that correlated with moral reasoning performance in the VBM analyses ( Figure 5 and Table 2). Associations between emotional response to Personal High Conflict moral dilemmas and integrity of the bilateral UF (i.e., mean FA) were examined within the bvFTD group. Negative correlations emerged for left and right UF, such that reduced integrity of the tracts (i.e., lower FA values) was associated with higher (i.e., an abnormal) feeling rating toward Personal High Conflict moral dilemmas (left: r = -.49, p = .01; right: r = -.50, p = .009) ( Figure 6).

[ INSERT FIGURE 6 HERE] Given the significant correlation between the emotional response to Personal High Conflict moral dilemmas and social conceptual knowledge (on the SNQ) that emerged in behavioural analyses, we performed partial correlations between emotional responses and integrity of the bilateral UF controlling for SNQ performance. These correlations no longer reached statistical significance (left: r = -.38, p = .09; right: -.36, p = .11), suggesting that social conceptual knowledge partially explains the relationship between the emotional response to moral conflict and integrity of the UF.

div.head: Tract of no interest
div.p: The ILF, which connects the ATL to the occipital lobe (Herbet et al., 2018), was employed as a white matter tract of no interest, to examine the specificity of the UF findings. No significant associations emerged between FA of the right or left ILF and feeling rating toward Personal High Conflict moral dilemmas in bvFTD patients (left: r = -.22, p = .17; right: -.28, p = .10).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Moral reasoning forms the backbone of social groups, with deleterious consequences when this foundation breaks down. Here, for the first time, we demonstrate that patients diagnosed with the behavioural variant of FTD display aberrant emotional responses to highly conflictual personal moral decisions. Importantly, their lack of negative affect is related, at least in part, to the deterioration of conceptual knowledge of what is right and wrong in social contexts. Our neuroimaging analyses revealed that diminished emotional responses to morally conflicting decisions in bvFTD reflects the degeneration of a distributed network of frontal, subcortical, and temporal regions, as well as their white-matter structural pathways. Crucially, the uncinate fasciculus (UF) emerged as a potential conduit by which social conceptual knowledge may influence emotional reactions to personal high-conflict moral dilemmas in bvFTD.

Deciding whether to personally harm somebody or indirectly cause the harm of many others is a highly conflictual endeavour that invariably invokes strong social emotions (Koenigs et al., 2007). Although bvFTD patients appeared capable of adjudicating between different courses of action in these scenarios, with no significant between-group differences in the actual moral decisions made or in their verbal justifications, the emotional responses in bvFTD departed considerably from that of Controls. Strikingly, bvFTD patients displayed an abnormal affective response specific to personal high-(but not low-) conflict moral dilemmas, whereby they reported feeling less negative emotion about their decisions compared with Controls. At its most extreme, 16 out of the 26 (i.e., 61.5%) of bvFTD patients reported that they felt 'extremely good' about their decision on at least one personal high-conflict dilemma. Previous studies of moral reasoning in bvFTD have explored associations between task performance and non-task related measures of emotion processing (Van den Stock et al., 2017), or alternatively have used experimenter ratings as a proxy for the patient's emotional responses (Fong et al., 2017).

Disrupted emotion recognition is a core clinical feature of bvFTD, most pronounced in relation to negative emotions (e.g., disgust, fear; Kumfor, Irish, Hodges, & Piguet, 2013). Crucially, the blunting of emotional reactions is also prominent in this syndrome (Neary et al., 1998), particularly in relation to self-conscious moral emotions such as guilt, shame, and embarrassment (Darby, Edersheim, & Price, 2016;Sturm, Ascher, Miller, & Levenson, 2008).

By directly surveying the subjective emotional experience of bvFTD patients in response to highly conflictual personal moral dilemmas, we reveal for the first time that the blunting of socially relevant self-conscious emotions in bvFTD extends to the arena of moral decisionmaking.

On the neural level, the blunted emotional response to personal high-conflict moral dilemmas in bvFTD was associated with reduced grey matter intensity in frontal and subcortical brain regions typically associated with emotion and salience processing (Frith, 2007;Seeley et al., 2007). Chief amongst these were the bilateral mPFC, orbitofrontal cortex, anterior cingulate cortex, insula, basal ganglia, amygdala, and hippocampus. This finding converges strongly with functional neuroimaging studies of personal moral reasoning in healthy individuals (Pascual et al., 2013), indicating that this affective network may be essential for personal moral reasoning (see Irish & van Kesteren, 2018). Of note, the brain regions that emerged in our analyses overlap with those implicated in moral emotions including guilt and shame in healthy individuals (Bastin, Harrison, Davey, Moll, & Whittle, 2016), along with the experience of Schadenfreude and envy in bvFTD (Santamaría-García et al., 2017). We tentatively suggest that fronto-subcortical atrophy disrupts the capacity to experience socially-oriented negative emotions in bvFTD, resulting in their seeming indifference towards the outcome of their
decisions.

An important aim of this study was to explore the contribution of social conceptual knowledge to personal high-conflict moral dilemmas. To date, the role of social rules and norms in moral reasoning has been studied almost exclusively in relation to moral development in childhood (Piaget, 1932). Here, we reveal its potential involvement in the unravelling of morality in neurodegeneration, via interactions with affective processes. Interestingly, we found a significant association between attenuated emotional reaction to these dilemmas and impaired conceptual knowledge of socially acceptable behaviour in bvFTD. Personal high-conflict moral dilemmas inherently involve the violation of social norms, regardless of one's decision (i.e., choosing to personally harm one person or bring about the harm of many others). Our findings therefore suggest that as conceptual knowledge of social standards and norms degrades in bvFTD, so too does the accompanying self-conscious, negative emotional experience when such standards are violated (Staller & Petta, 2001). For example, if these patients lose the conceptual knowledge that it is wrong to harm others, they may not feel remorseful when choosing this course of action in the moral dilemma. Supporting this proposal is the observation that bvFTD patients tend to judge intentional harm (i.e., the type of harm involved in personal high-conflict dilemmas) as more permissible than healthy subjects (Baez et al., 2016). Interestingly, however, the altered emotional responses in bvFTD do not seem to impact upon their actual moral judgments. As such, rather than representing a global decay in moral reasoning, the severe alterations in moral behaviour witnessed in bvFTD likely reflect the dynamic interplay between degraded social conceptual knowledge and blunted affective responsiveness.

In addition to regions typically associated with affective processing, an attenuated emotional response to personal high-conflict moral dilemmas was related to reduced grey matter integrity of the bilateral temporal poles. The ATLs have a well-established role in representing conceptual knowledge, including knowledge of social rules, norms, and socially appropriate behaviour (Olson et al., 2013;Panchal et al., 2016;Zahn et al., 2007). While ATL activation is commonplace during functional neuroimaging studies of personal moral reasoning (Pascual et al., 2013), the precise role of this region in moral decision making has thus far remained unclear. Taken together with the behavioural findings, we suggest that social conceptual knowledge represented in the ATLs may guide the appropriate affective response to highly conflictual personal moral dilemmas. Indeed, these complex socially-oriented emotional reactions are likely subtended by interacting emotional and social conceptual processes, supported by frontal and temporal regions, respectively. Accordingly, we can infer that the seamless and coordinated interplay between these processes hinges upon successful communication between frontal and temporal structures, suggesting a critical role for white matter pathways which connect these regions.

This proposal was borne out in our diffusion-weighted imaging analyses. Indeed, we revealed a robust association between the abnormal emotional response to personal high-conflict moral dilemmas in bvFTD and reduced integrity of the bilateral uncinate fasciculus (UF), a tract connecting the orbitofrontal/mPFC to the ATLs, but not with the control tract, the ILF.

Compellingly, when social conceptual knowledge was controlled for, the relationship between integrity of the UF and emotional response to moral dilemmas no longer reached statistical significance. This suggests that social conceptual knowledge partially explains the relationship between the emotional response to moral conflict and integrity of the UF. While the UF has been suggested to support socioemotional functioning (Von Der Heide et al., 2013), the precise mechanism by which it operates has not yet been delineated. Its anatomical position, lying at the interface between regions specialised for affective (i.e., orbitofrontal/mPFC) and conceptual (i.e., ATL) cortical regions, offers important clues. For the first time, our findings suggest that during personal high-conflict moral dilemmas, the UF may form the pathway by which social conceptual knowledge (from the ATLs) is integrated with information represented in the mPFC (e.g., social schemas, Gilboa & Marlatte, 2017;Wilson et al., 2020) to inform the emotional response. The degradation of this tract in bvFTD likely impedes the transfer of socioemotional information between frontal and temporal regions, further blunting these patients' emotional responses under conditions of high moral conflict.

div.head: Conclusions and Future Directions
div.p: Due to the legal, ethical, and societal implications of moral transgressions, it is imperative to reach a precise understanding of the cognitive and neural bases of moral reasoning. Here, by leveraging a large sample of bvFTD patients, we demonstrate how affective processing and social conceptual knowledge likely interact during the service of personal high-conflict moral decision making. Based on our findings, we propose that knowledge of social norms, stored in the ATLs, is conveyed to the mPFC where it is incorporated in the production of an emotional response to personal, highly conflictual moral dilemmas. In order to confirm this hypothesised directionality, future studies examining functional and effective connectivity between mPFC and ATLs, and its relationship with specific aspects of emotion and conceptual knowledge during personal moral reasoning, will be of utmost interest. While we did not have the statistical power in the current study, it will also be important to explore whether, and how, these processes vary across different types of personal high-conflict moral dilemmas (Rosas & Koenigs, 2014). Finally, despite not forming the focus of our investigations, significant potential scope exists for delineating additional neurocognitive processes involved in personal moral decision making, such as episodic memory (see Craver et al., 2016;McCormick et al., 2016 and Supplementary Results), cognitive control (Greene, Nystrom, Engell, Darley, & Cohen, 2004), and theory of mind (Roberts, Henry, & Molenberghs, 2019;. By unpacking the mechanisms of altered morality in bvFTD, we provide crucial clinical information for understanding and treating this challenging symptom, in turn paving the way for targeted behavioural interventions. and the Australian Research Council Centre of Excellence in Cognition and its Disorders (CE11000102). We are grateful to the research participants involved with the ForeFront research studies. The authors acknowledge the technical assistance provided by the Sydney These funding sources had no involvement in the study design, collection, analysis and interpretation of data, writing the manuscript, and in the decision to submit the manuscript for publication.

div.head: Competing interests
div.p: The authors report no competing interests.

figure.figDesc: 2011) and AD (McKhann et al., 2011), with diagnoses made by an experienced behavioural neurologist in consultation with a neuropsychologist and occupational therapist, based on clinical and cognitive assessments and structural neuroimaging. Control participants scored in the cognitively normal range (i.e., 88/100 or above) on a general cognitive screening measure, the Addenbrooke's Cognitive Examination-III (ACE-III) (Hsieh, Schubert, Hoon, Mioshi, & Hodges, 2013). Exclusion criteria for all participants included a significant history of another psychiatric or neurological condition or alcohol or substance abuse, and limited English proficiency. Ethics approval was obtained from the South Eastern Sydney Local Health District and University of New South Wales ethics committees. In accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki, informed consent was obtained from all participants or their person responsible. Neuropsychological assessment Participants completed a comprehensive battery of neuropsychological assessment tasks. This included a measure of global cognition (ACE-III), along with more detailed examination of specific cognitive domains including verbal attention and working memory (Digit Span Forward and Backward Maximum Span; Wechsler, 1997), language (ACE-III Language subscale; Hsieh et al., 2013), verbal (Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test [RAVLT] Delayed

figure.figDesc: displays the average percentage of Utilitarian responses provided by bvFTD, AD, and Control groups for each moral dilemma type. Mauchly's test indicated that the assumption of sphericity had been violated for the main effect of dilemma type (c 2 (2) = 20.56 p < .001).

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Violin plots representing the average percentage of Utilitarian responses provided by each group on each of the moral dilemma types. AD = Alzheimer's disease; bvFTD = behavioural variant frontotemporal dementia.

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Violin plots representing the average certainty, vividness, and feeling ratings for the Personal Low (A) and High (B) Conflict moral decisions provided by each group. AD = Alzheimer's disease; bvFTD = behavioural variant frontotemporal dementia. Asterisk denotes significant difference between groups at *p < .05.

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: Voxel-based morphometry (VBM) analyses showing brain areas with decreased grey matter intensity in behavioural variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) compared with Controls. Coloured voxels emerged as significant in a threshold-free cluster enhancement (TFCE) analysis at p < .005, corrected for familywise error, with a cluster extent threshold of 200 contiguous voxels. All t values ≥ 3.29 (Supplementary Table 1). Clusters are overlaid on the Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) standard brain. L = Left.

figure.head: Figure 5 .
figure.figDesc: Voxel-based morphometry (VBM) correlation analyses showing brain areas in which grey matter intensity negatively correlates with emotional responses to personal high conflict moral dilemmas in behavioural variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) patients combined with Controls. Coloured voxels emerged as significant in a threshold-free cluster enhancement (TFCE) analysis at p < .01, corrected for familywise error, with a cluster extent threshold of 200 contiguous voxels. Clusters are overlaid on the Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) standard brain. L = left.

figure.head: Figure 6 .
figure.figDesc: Relationship between Fractional Anisotropy (FA) values for the left and right uncincate fasciculi (UF) and feeling rating toward Personal High Conflict moral dilemmas in the behavioural variant of frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD).

body.note: Further work has parsed Personal High Conflict moral dilemmas into discrete subcategories(Rosas & Koenigs, 2014). Here, the selected dilemmas encompassed a range of these subtypes, in relatively equal proportions to that of the full set of scenarios(Koenigs et al., 2007) (seeSupplementary Results).

For the first 8 participants that were tested (6 bvFTD patients and 2 Controls), individuals were required to choose from one of the example options (or the 'other' category) during the main task, in order to explain their decision-making process. The methodology was altered after observing that participants' responses did not always fit cleanly into one of the provided categories, and it was thought that an open-ended question would provide a broader and more accurate reflection of the decision-making process.

These results remained almost identical after including task methodology as a covariate (i.e., whether participants completed the open-ended versus multiple-choice version of the question, see Footnote 2) (Personal Low Conflict: F(2, 56) = .54, p = .59, hp 2 = .02; High Conflict: F(2, 56) = .50, p = .61, hp 2 = .02).

div.head: Acknowledgements and Funding
div.p: This study was supported by ForeFront, a large collaborative research group dedicated to the study of neurodegenerative diseases and funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council of Australia Program Grant (#1132524), Dementia Research Team Grant (#1095127)
